awd_titl_txt: UNS:  Temporal Monitoring of Waterborne Contamination: An Engineered Substrate with Selective Cryptosporidium Adsorption Properties
awd_abstract_narration:
1511784
Jellison

Cryptosporidium is a waterborne parasite responsible for a gastrointestinal disease that can be fatal for the elderly and immunocompromised individuals. Cryptosporidiosis has no medical cure, and since oocysts may not be completely removed/inactivated in municipal water treatment plants, monitoring Cryptosporidium contamination in source waters is necessary to identify public health risks and determine where limited budgets should most effectively be spent to protect consumers from waterborne exposure to pathogenic oocysts. Current sample methodology for Cryptosporidium monitoring in water supplies (EPA Method 1623.1) relies on filtering and processing 10 L of water, providing a "snapshot" of river conditions at the time of filtration. The primary goal of the team is to develop a cheaper and more reliable method for detecting Cryptosporidium oocysts in public water supplies.

Previous work in the PIs laboratory has shown that Cryptosporidium spp. oocysts can robustly attach to biofilms; however, biofilm sampling is limited by the inherent variability in biofilm growth. Taking inspiration from this biofilm sorptive nature, the current team will focus on developing a manufactured substrate with fixed sorptive capacity for Cryptosporidium oocysts. These substrates will be engineered with surface features complementary to the oocyst that allow either non-specific adhesion through surface chemistry that would allow for hydrogen bonding or specific adhesion by imprinting a molecular fingerprint of the oocyst surface onto the substrate. These substrates will be analyzed initially in lab-scale bioreactors, which will provide crucial binding parameters. The substrates will then be deployed in natural waterways to determine the robustness of the substrates, with the goal of eventually providing a more temporal look at the health of the waterway. This research program is highly interdisciplinary, providing an excellent opportunity for student training through new courses and hands-on research opportunities. The PI and co-PI have a history of mentoring students from underrepresented groups in STEM, and will continue to recruit from these groups for inclusion in this project. In addition, several educational programs will be developed in collaboration with Broughal Middle School, a nearby Title 1 school. These educational programs will include brochures, projects, and field education focused on water safety and conservation.

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merit 

Cryptosporidium parvum is a waterborne pathogen that causes severe gastrointestinal disease for which there is currently no medical cure. Understanding the fate and transport of C. parvum oocysts in the environment is critical to protect public health. This project focused on elucidating the biophysical and chemical factors affecting C. parvum oocyst attachment to surfaces to inform the development of innovative technologies for parasite detection and treatment technologies to protect public health.

Experimental work identified calcium as the predominant factor that bridges the carboxylic functional groups on biofilm and oocyst surfaces to cause attachment (Figure 1); calcium bridging was shown to be important for oocyst attachment regardless of water chemistry or hydrodynamic shear stress (ranging from laminar to turbulent flow). Higher hydrodynamic shear stress was associated with faster initial oocyst attachment to biofilms, while lower shear was associated with greater numbers of oocysts attached to biofilms at equilibrium. The binding strength of C. parvum oocysts to carboxylic functional groups increased over a 5-week period as the oocysts aged, followed by a decrease in the binding strength which may be related to structural or biochemical changes in the outer wall-bound glycosylated proteins.

The experimental work informed the design of engineered surfaces which were built and tested to determine attachment efficiencies for C. parvum oocysts. Whole cell imprinting of polydimethylsiloxane (PDMS) was used to create selective and sensitive surfaces for the capture of C. parvum oocysts in water (Figure 2); the overall binding affinity was determined to be less than that of highly specific antibodies, but on par with standard antibodies and immune-enabled technologies. These results demonstrate the potential for developing devices using cell-imprinting for use in waterborne pathogen analysis. Polydopamine (PD) thin films promoted C. parvum oocyst attachment in waters of varying chemistry, and calcium-mediated attachment was observed; however, PD thin films were not selective for C. parvum attachment (Figure 3). PD thin films showed promise as antibacterial surfaces, and oocyst excystation was observed on the PD surface, which suggests potential applications of PD thin films as deactivation agents or as biomimetic surfaces to study oocyst behavior. Work is ongoing to modify the PD thin films with glycan moieties more selective for C. parvum oocysts.

Broader Impacts

This project supported the research and education of three graduate students (2 female Ph.D. students, 1 male M.S. student) in environmental engineering and one female Ph.D. student in materials science and engineering.

The integration of research and education was a high priority in this project. Curriculum was developed to teach middle and high school students about the importance of safe drinking water, common drinking water contaminants, and technologies to purify drinking water in areas with limited resources; this curriculum was delivered to 163 students at Broughal Middle School in Bethlehem, PA and 234 high school students in Sierra Leone. The Broughal Middle School students, with input from the high school students in Sierra Leone, drafted a water manual titled Clean Water for Everyone (Figure 4); the manual, designed by kids and for kids, describes the basics of water quality and clean drinking water. The manual is currently under final revision, and the ultimate goal is to publish the manual to disseminate the information to a broader audience in both the U.S. and in the developing world.
